intro.para: After learning how to compute the determinant of a matrix, let us now turn to rules for computing with determinants. The essence here is: these rules apply even if we do not know the number value of the determinant of a given matrix. In subsequent sections we will use these rules to discover what a determinant actually means via the concept of ‘oriented volume’. Moreover, we will develop a more efficient method of computing determinants of large matrices.

subsection.body.para:
To discuss the algebraic properties of the determinant of a square matrix \Mtrx{A}, it is advantageous to express \Mtrx{A} in terms of its
column vectors
Example of column vectors
For example,
\Mtrx{A} = \left[ \begin{array}{rrr} 1 & 4 & 6 \\ 3 & 1 & 2 \\ -4 & 0 & 1 \end{array} \right]
has the column vectors
A_1 = \left[ \begin{array}{r} 1 \\ 3 \\ -4 \end{array} \right],\qquad A_2 = \left[ \begin{array}{r} 4 \\ 1 \\ 0 \end{array} \right],\qquad A_3 = \left[ \begin{array}{r} 6 \\ 2 \\ 1 \end{array} \right]
: \Mtrx{A}=[A_1\ \dots\ A_n].
